message.content: {"responses": [{"question_id": "TT4G35A", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence helps teachers write or improve lesson plans.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35B", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence enables teachers to adapt learning material to different students' abilities.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35C", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence assists teachers in supporting students individually.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35D", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence supports students with specific needs (e.g. multilingual learners, students with special education needs).", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35E", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence helps teachers automate administrative tasks.", "response": "Strongly agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35F", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence enables students to misrepresent others' work as their own.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35G", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence makes recommendations that may not be appropriate or correct.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35H", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence amplifies biases that reinforce students' misconceptions.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35I", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence jeopardises the privacy and security of student data.", "response": "Agree"}, {"question_id": "TT4G35J", "input_statement": "Artificial intelligence suggests unsuitable pedagogical approaches that teachers would use with students.", "response": "Disagree"}]}
message.reasoning_content:
I need to respond to a survey as a primary or secondary school teacher from Kazakhstan about AI in education. Let me carefully consider each statement and provide thoughtful responses based on a teacher's perspective.

Let me go through each one:

[TT4G35A] - AI helps teachers write or improve lesson plans.
This is generally true - AI tools can assist with generating ideas, structuring content, and providing suggestions for lesson plans. I would agree with this.

[TT4G35B] - AI enables teachers to adapt learning material to different students' abilities.
This is a capability AI has shown - adaptive learning systems can tailor content to different proficiency levels. I would agree.

[TT4G35C] - AI assists teachers in supporting students individually.
AI can help with personalized feedback, tutoring systems, and individual support. I would agree.

[TT4G35D] - AI supports students with specific needs.
AI can help with translation tools, accessibility features, etc. This is a positive capability. I would agree.

[TT4G35E] - AI helps teachers automate administrative tasks.
This is definitely true - grading, scheduling, attendance tracking can be automated. I would agree.

[TT4G35F] - AI enables students to misrepresent others' work as their own.
This is a concern - AI tools like writing assistants could be misused for academic dishonesty. I would agree this is a real risk.

[TT4G35G] - AI makes recommendations that may not be appropriate or correct.
AI systems do have limitations and can make errors or inappropriate suggestions. I would agree.

[TT4G35H] - AI amplifies biases that reinforce students' misconceptions.
This is a known issue with AI systems trained on biased data. I would agree this is a concern.

[TT4G35I] - AI jeopardises the privacy and security of student data.
This is a valid concern - data security and privacy issues with AI systems are real. I would agree.


[TT4G35J] - AI suggests unsuitable pedagogical approaches that teachers would use with students.
AI might recommend methods that don't fit best practices or local context, so this is a legitimate concern worth acknowledging.

I should recognize both the genuine advantages AI offers for instruction and administration, while remaining alert to the real risks around academic integrity, data protection, bias, and pedagogical appropriateness. My responses will reflect agreement with the beneficial capabilities while also validating the concerns teachers reasonably have about implementation challenges.

I'm confirming agreement across all ten statements—the positive ones (A through E) capture real ways AI can enhance lesson design, personalization, and workload management, while the cautionary ones (F through J) address genuine issues like cheating potential, recommendation quality, algorithmic bias, privacy vulnerabilities, and the risk of pedagogically flawed suggestions. This balanced stance acknowledges that AI is a useful tool with meaningful limitations that educators need to navigate carefully.
